description: From late Old English, from Old French legat, from Latin legatus (nominal use of perfect passive participle of lego (“bequeath, send as envoy”)).

entries.meaning: A deputy representing the pope, specifically a papal ambassador sent on special ecclesiastical missions.

examples: The dark figure on the raised white terrace; legate of the sun facing the sun; the most ancient royal power.

entries.meaning: The deputy of a provincial governor or general in ancient Rome.
examples: Legate, I had the news last night—my cohort ordered homeBy ships to Portus Itius and thence by road to Rome.

verbs.description: legate (third-person singular simple present legates, present participle legating, simple past and past participle legated)
